SB/SE Revenue Officers
Table of Contents
Repeater Evaluation Process Flow Chart
Repeater or Pyramiding Taxpayers

) Purpose: This IRM section provides the procedural instructions to identify work repeater and in-business pyramiding taxpayers. By following the Scope and dures and initiating appropriate collection remedies, revenue officers can prevent and stop the pyramiding of trust fund liabilities. a. Deﬁnes and describes the steps to identify a repeater taxpayer. b. Deﬁnes and describes the steps to take when encountering a in-business taxpayer. (

) Audience: Field Collection revenue officers and group managers will be primary users of this IRM. Revenue officers are responsible for making tion determinations including appropriate enforcement actions and Trust Recovery Penalty recommendations. Group managers have review and approval authority for certain enforcement and Trust Fund Recovery recommendations. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Collection Policy (
) Program Owner: Collection Policy Headquarters, an organization within Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) division. (
) Primary Stakeholders: Revenue Officers, Offer in Compromise Centralized Case Processing, and Advisory. (
) Program Goals: Identify and prevent the pyramiding of tax liabilities and tax repeaters into ﬁling and paying compliance. (

) Promoting payroll tax compliance is a top priority for the IRS as two thirds federal taxes are collected through the payroll tax system. Early and continuous monitoring of federal tax deposits can prevent in-business taxpayers from pyramiding tax debt and lower the nation’s tax gap. Field lections’ proper identiﬁcation of repeater and pyramiding taxpayers are to ensure appropriate collection remedies are taken to prevent or stop miding. (
) The policies in this IRM are based on the following: • IRC §
, Levy And Distraint • IRC §
, Lien for Taxes • IRC §
, Failure to collect and pay over tax, or attempt to evade defeat tax • Policy Statement
, Collection Enforced Through Seizure and Assets Occurs Only After Thorough Consideration of All Factors and Alternative Collection Method • Title
, Deposit Rules for Taxes Under the Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA) and Withheld Income Taxes • IRC §
, Jurisdiction of District Court (
) The Director of Collection Policy is responsible for overseeing policy and cedures regarding repeater and pyramiding taxpayers. (
) Revenue officers are responsible for identifying and properly working ing and repeater cases. Field Collection Group Manager responsibilities for monitoring pyramiding taxpayers are found in IRM
, Collection Manager, Territory Manager, and Area Director Operational Aid.

5.7.8.1.5 (01-09-2020)Terms/Deﬁnitions/ Acronyms
The table below lists common acronyms used in this section.
Acronym Deﬁnition EFTPS Electronic Funds Transfer Payment System FTD Federal Tax Deposit NFTL Notice of Federal Tax Lien TFRP Trust Fund Recovery Penalty
NFTL Notice of Federal Tax Lien TFRP Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (

) The large number of business taxpayers who repeatedly accrue liabilities and/or do not ﬁle their tax returns timely, is a major compliance problem. personnel need to properly identify these taxpayers and take appropriate action to bring them into tax compliance. (
) A repeater is deﬁned as a taxpayer who has more than one module with a taxpayer delinquent account (TDA) or taxpayer delinquent investigation (TDI) that came into existence (see IRM
)(c)) within the last two years (
cycles from the current cycle). Once identiﬁed as a repeater, if the taxpayer maintains

cycles of compliance (no TDA/TDI delinquencies), they are no longer considered a repeater. If the taxpayer has multiple delinquencies, they are only considered a repeater if those delinquencies occurred within
cycles from the current cycle. (
) Deﬁnition of terms. a. The current cycle is the cycle corresponding to the current date. b. Delinquency status is deﬁned as a master ﬁle status of
for Collection System,
for Field Queue,
for Field Collection, or

for TDI. c. The date a delinquency ﬁrst came into existence is determined on a module by module basis. There can be multiple delinquency statuses within each module. In order to determine the date of a delinquency, review the master ﬁle delinquency status history for the ﬁrst date a quency status [i.e., master ﬁle status
, or
] arose within the module.

a. The current cycle is the cycle corresponding to the current date. b. Delinquency status is deﬁned as a master ﬁle status of
for Collection System,
for Field Queue,
for Field Collection, or

Repeater or Pyramiding Taxpayers 5.7.8

Module Delinquency Example 1: • 10-12-2013 master ﬁle balance due ﬁrst notice status 21 • 12-1-2014 master ﬁle status 22 • 5-10-2015 master ﬁle status 24 • 8-30-2016 master ﬁle status 26 • 12-1-2014 is the date a delinquency ﬁrst came into existence for this module.
12-1-2014 is the date a delinquency ﬁrst came into existence for
d. A module can be currently open or resolved. To determine if a taxpayer is a repeater, review all modules within the last
cycles. If the account was open for a minor issue that was quickly resolved, use discretion to determine if the taxpayer is truly a repeater.
Repeater Evaluation Process Flow Chart. This is the start of the ﬂow chart.
Starting with the current cycle, are there any other modules with delin
quencies that came into existence in the immediate past two years or one hundred and four cycles, from this cycle? If yes, the taxpayer is a repeater. If no, continue to process four.

Starting with the cycle just prior to the cycle of that one delinquency, are there any other modules with delinquencies that ﬁrst came into existence in the immediate past two years or one hundred and four cycles from that cycle?
If yes, continue to process ﬁve.
If no, the taxpayer is not a repeater.
*(see note at end)
Are there two or more delinquencies?
If yes, the taxpayer is a repeater.
If no, continue to process six. Process Six
Is there at least one delinquency?
If yes, continue to process seven.
If no, the taxpayer is not a repeater. Process Seven
Starting with the cycle just prior to the cycle of that one delinquency, there any other modules with delinquencies that ﬁrst came into one hundred and four cycles prior to that cycle?
If yes, continue to process ﬁve.

If no, the taxpayer is not a repeater. Note: This part of the process is structured to determine if a taxpayer, who was labeled as a repeater in the past, is still a repeater because they failed to achieve a good compliance record for a two year period. It is possible that this part of the process may continue to loop back to the beginning of the taxpayer’s ﬁling history. (

) The large number of in-business taxpayers pyramiding trust fund tax is a major compliance problem. A pyramiding taxpayer is deﬁned as: a. In business b. Not current with federal tax deposits (FTDs) c. Has two or more trust fund modules assigned to Field Collection. (

) A taxpayer who pyramids tax liabilities is not demonstrating a good faith to comply with their tax obligations. Early intervention and the continuous monitoring of federal tax deposits can prevent taxpayers from pyramiding. (
) Taxpayers who make timely and adequate federal tax deposits after contact and ﬁle all outstanding tax returns are in compliance. These taxpayers are longer considered pyramiding taxpayers. (
) When determining the appropriate course of action to resolve these consider previous efforts to educate the taxpayer about the importance of remaining compliant. (
) Field Collection should be aware that taxpayers who use Form
, Employ- er’s Annual Federal Tax Return, can pyramid tax liabilities when payroll tax Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
V
Starting with the cycle just prior to the cycle of that one delinquency, there any other modules with delinquencies that ﬁrst came into one hundred and four cycles prior to that cycle?
If yes, continue to process ﬁve.

If no, the taxpayer is not a repeater. Note: This part of the process is structured to determine if a taxpayer, who was labeled as a repeater in the past, is still a repeater because they failed to achieve a good compliance record for a two year period. It is possible that this part of the process may continue to loop back to the beginning of the taxpayer’s ﬁling history.

The large number of in-business taxpayers pyramiding trust fund tax is a major compliance problem. A pyramiding taxpayer is deﬁned as: a. In business b. Not current with federal tax deposits (FTDs) c. Has two or more trust fund modules assigned to Field Collection. A taxpayer who pyramids tax liabilities is not demonstrating a good faith to comply with their tax obligations. Early intervention and the continuous monitoring of federal tax deposits can prevent taxpayers from pyramiding. Taxpayers who make timely and adequate federal tax deposits after contact and ﬁle all outstanding tax returns are in compliance. These taxpayers are longer considered pyramiding taxpayers. When determining the appropriate course of action to resolve these consider previous efforts to educate the taxpayer about the importance of remaining compliant. Field Collection should be aware that taxpayers who use Form
, Employ- er’s Annual Federal Tax Return, can pyramid tax liabilities when payroll tax

Field Collection should be aware that taxpayers who use Form 944, Employ- er’s Annual Federal Tax Return, can pyramid tax liabilities when payroll tax

Trust Fund (
) If a taxpayer is identiﬁed as a repeater, attempt initial contact within
days from receipt of the case (see IRM

, Initial Contact Time Frame) focus on preventing the taxpayer from pyramiding. When the taxpayer has a power of attorney, an appointment will be made to meet the taxpayer and her representative at the taxpayer’s place of business to provide an to review payroll records, view assets, and observe the business operation the event a risk analysis determination is necessary. If initial contact at the place of business is not possible, the reason should be documented in the tegrated Collection System (ICS) case history, and a ﬁeld call to view assets must be done before submitting the case for closure, if practical (see IRM
), Initial Contact). (
) The Taxpayer Bill or Rights describes ten basic rights that all taxpayers have when dealing with the IRS. To help you understand what these rights mean you and how they apply, read Publication
, Your Rights as a Taxpayer, available at https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p
pdf, or visit https://www.irs.gov/ taxpayer-bill-of-rights. (
) During initial contact conduct a Trust Fund Recovery Penalty (TFRP) using Form

, Report of Interview with Individual Relative to Trust Fund Recovery Penalty or Personal Liability for Excise Taxes. Calculate the TFRP using the Automated Trust Fund Recovery System (ATFR) based on current assessment and provide the amount to the taxpayer. Review with the taxpayer the potential assessment, TFRP procedures, and the collection process. See IRM
, Establishing Responsibility and Willfulness for the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty, and IRM
), Initial Contact, for tional information. (

) During initial contact advise the taxpayer they will need to stay current with their federal tax deposits (FTDs). Document the case history with the taxpay- er’s deposit schedule (i.e. monthly, semiweekly). Secure electronic funds transfer payment system (EFTPS) conﬁrmation, such as an electronic fund transfer number, and request the taxpayer send conﬁrmation to verify the liness and accuracy of deposits, until their case is resolved. The revenue officer will monitor compliance with FTDs on ICS and verify that they are accurately. See IRM
, Taxpayer Contacts, for speciﬁc requirements regarding the information that must be obtained during initial contact. (
) It is important for revenue officers to recognize the difference between a taxpayer identiﬁed as a repeater (IRM
) and one that is pyramiding

). Any decision involving case actions such as an installment agreement, closure as currently not collectible, or an offer in compromise should not be based solely on this determination but in conjunction with relevant aspects of the case. These include their cooperation working with Internal Revenue Service to resolve their tax delinquencies, their ability to remain current with present and future tax obligations, and their ability to remain solvent while making payments on their delinquent taxes. (

) Pyramiding must be stopped immediately. Advise the taxpayer enforcement action will be taken if acceptable proof of compliance is not provided while their delinquent tax issues are resolved. If the taxpayer continues to use all appropriate remedies to bring the taxpayer into compliance. If routine case actions are not effective in stopping the taxpayer from pyramiding, consider alternative solutions including seizure of physical assets and injunc- tive relief.
or Pyramiding Taxpayers
page (
) Taxpayers who consistently make timely and adequate federal tax deposits, after contact, are in compliance and should not be considered a pyramiding taxpayer. Follow procedures in IRM

, Determining Whether To Pursue the TFRP in Installment Agreement or Bankruptcy Situations, and IRM Installment Agreements, BMF Installment Agreements, when considering an installment agreement for these taxpayers. (
) Secure sufficient ﬁnancial information during initial contact so enforcement action can be taken if necessary. (
) If it is determined that the business is “Out of Business” or is no longer required to ﬁle returns, immediately complete Form
, Masterﬁle ENTITY Change, or Form
, Request for Terminal Action, to close out the ﬁling quirements on IDRS. Continue procedures to pursue the TFRP investigation. (See IRM
, Investigation and Recommendation of the Trust Fund Recovery Penalty). (
) Make a determination and document the case history with the taxpayer’s to pay current and delinquent taxes. (
) Set speciﬁc deadlines when requesting information from the taxpayer. Use Form
, Summary of Taxpayer Contact, in face-to-face meetings to give taxpayer a clear understanding of the consequences for failure to comply. On Form
list the requirement to make FTDs and the date required to veriﬁcation and give the taxpayer a copy as a reminder. (
) Installment agreements are not appropriate for taxpayers who continue to accrue tax liabilities after contact because they are not in compliance. See
, BMF Installment Agreements, and IRM

, Considerations for In-Business Installment Agreements, for the procedures to follow when ering an installment agreement for Business Master File (BMF) taxpayers are making FTDs after contact and are no longer pyramiding. (
) Cases involving repeater and pyramiding taxpayers will often require ment action. On initial contact, issue Letter

, Notice of Intent to Levy Notice of Your Right to a Hearing, with all required enclosures. If prior history or research indicates the taxpayer has limited to no assets and/or has not made deposits, consider issuing Letter
, Letter to Employer - You Deposited Federal Employment Taxes (see IRM
, Overview of the
Process). Receipt of Letter
and/or Letter
during initial contact may prompt the repeater or pyramiding taxpayer to cooperate. a. If contact is made, explain to the taxpayer the Letter

is being to ensure their compliance with ﬁling and paying requirements and to comply with the revenue officer’s request will result in enforcement action. The revenue officer must provide the taxpayer with their due process (CDP) rights and explain the CDP process to them. The right to submit a CDP appeal will expire
days after issuance of the letter. The taxpayer still retains the right to request an “equivalent” hearing (See IRM
, Equivalent Hearing (EH) and Timeliness EH Requests) and/or to appeal a speciﬁc planned or actual collection action under the Collection Appeals Program (CAP) (See IRM
, Collection Appeals Program). b. If attempts to contact the taxpayer are unsuccessful, issue Letter
and consider immediate enforcement action as the next course of Internal Revenue Manual
Repeater or Pyramiding Taxpayers 5.7.8

Taxpayers who consistently make timely and adequate federal tax deposits, after contact, are in compliance and should not be considered a pyramiding taxpayer. Follow procedures in IRM 5.7.4.8, Determining Whether To Pursue the TFRP in Installment Agreement or Bankruptcy Situations, and IRM 5.14.7, Installment Agreements, BMF Installment Agreements, when considering an

Installment agreements are not appropriate for taxpayers who continue to accrue tax liabilities after contact because they are not in compliance. See IRM 5.14.7, BMF Installment Agreements, and IRM 5.7.4.8.1, Considerations for In-Business Installment Agreements, for the procedures to follow when consid- ering an installment agreement for Business Master File (BMF) taxpayers who are making FTDs after contact and are no longer pyramiding.
If contact is made, explain to the taxpayer the Letter

is being issued to ensure their compliance with ﬁling and paying requirements and failure to comply with the revenue officer’s request will result in enforcement action. The revenue officer must provide the taxpayer with their collection due process (CDP) rights and explain the CDP process to them. The right to submit a CDP appeal will expire
days after issuance of the letter. The taxpayer still retains the right to request an “equivalent” hearing (See IRM
, Equivalent Hearing (EH) and Timeliness of EH Requests) and/or to appeal a speciﬁc planned or actual collection action under the Collection Appeals Program (CAP) (See IRM
, Collection Appeals Program). If attempts to contact the taxpayer are unsuccessful, issue Letter
and consider immediate enforcement action as the next course of action.
If attempts to contact the taxpayer are unsuccessful, issue Letter 1058 and consider immediate enforcement action as the next course of
Trust Fund c. If the taxpayer previously requested a CDP hearing for employment and pyramided additional liabilities, a Disqualiﬁed Employment Tax Levy (DETL) may be appropriate (see IRM

, Disqualiﬁed Tax Levy). Advise the taxpayer of post levy CDP rights on the tax identiﬁed in the DETL. d. In situations where the taxpayer is non-compliant, and there are no levy sources, revenue officers should consider civil injunctions against the taxpayer (see IRM
, Civil Injunctions under IRC §
(a) Restrain Pyramiding, and IRM
, Injunction Monitoring for Trust Fund Pyramiding Cases). (
) Make a lien determination within the prescribed time frames following IRM

, Federal Tax Liens, Notice of Lien Determinations, for speciﬁc on whether to ﬁle or defer ﬁling. The taxpayer’s ﬁling and payment should always be considered when the non-ﬁling or deferring of a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) is being determined. The NFTL should generally be ﬁled on pyramiding taxpayers unless group manager approval is secured the criteria to defer or not ﬁle is met (See IRM

, Determination for “Do-Not-File” or Deferring the NFTL Filing). Taxpayers have the right to be informed and to appeal an IRS decision in an independent forum. If a NFTL ﬁling is proposed, advise the taxpayer of their right to ﬁle a CAP. Also explain to the taxpayer their right to request a CDP under IRC §
once the has been ﬁled (See IRM
, Appeals Processes Involving Liens). (
) If levy sources are exhausted and the repeater or pyramiding taxpayer has assets which can be seized to resolve or offset the liability, consider issuing Letter
, and Notice

, Deposit Requirements for Employment Taxes. a. These procedures should be used in the most egregious cases of non- compliance and where attempts at collection have already been unproductive. b. Issuance of the Letter
, will assist in promoting compliance. c. Once the Letter
, is issued, subsequent delinquencies by the will be accelerated to the ﬁeld for prompt enforcement action. (
) During taxpayer contact, when the taxpayer asks to be referred to the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) or meets TAS criteria (See IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria), and the taxpayer’s issue cannot be resolved within
hours, prepare and forward Form
, Request for Taxpayer Advocate Service Assistance And Application for Taxpayer tance Order, to the Local Taxpayer Advocate (See IRM

, Taxpayer Service). Generally, when a case has been assigned to TAS, collection such as NFTL ﬁling and levy issuance, should be suspended until TAS has a reasonable opportunity to resolve the disputed issue. Note: If the issue cannot be completely resolved within
hours but steps are taken to begin resolving the taxpayer’s issues within
hours, do not forward Form
except in cases where the taxpayer has requested to be assigned to TAS unless the case meets the criteria in IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria.
If levy sources are exhausted and the repeater or pyramiding taxpayer has no assets which can be seized to resolve or offset the liability, consider issuing Letter
, and Notice

, Deposit Requirements for Employment Taxes. a. These procedures should be used in the most egregious cases of non- compliance and where attempts at collection have already been unproductive. b. Issuance of the Letter
, will assist in promoting compliance. c. Once the Letter

, is issued, subsequent delinquencies by the taxpayer will be accelerated to the ﬁeld for prompt enforcement action. During taxpayer contact, when the taxpayer asks to be referred to the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) or meets TAS criteria (See IRM
, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria), and the taxpayer’s issue cannot be resolved within
hours, prepare and forward Form
, Request for Taxpayer Advocate Service Assistance And Application for Taxpayer Assis- tance Order, to the Local Taxpayer Advocate (See IRM

, Taxpayer Advocate Service). Generally, when a case has been assigned to TAS, collection actions, such as NFTL ﬁling and levy issuance, should be suspended until TAS has had a reasonable opportunity to resolve the disputed issue. Note: If the issue cannot be completely resolved within
hours but steps are taken to begin resolving the taxpayer’s issues within
hours, do not forward Form
except in cases where the taxpayer has requested to be assigned to TAS unless the case meets the criteria in IRM

, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria), and the taxpayer’s issue cannot be resolved within
hours, prepare and forward Form

If the issue cannot be completely resolved within
hours but steps are taken to begin resolving the taxpayer’s issues within

Repeater or Pyramiding Taxpayers
) The repeater taxpayer’s history of non-compliance is an important factor contemplating the seizure of an in-business taxpayer’s assets (See Policy of Statement P-
and IRM
, Policy Statements for the Collecting Process ). If the taxpayer accrues additional unpaid trust fund liabilities after contact, conduct a risk analysis and a seizure should be made (see IRM

,Alternative Methods of Collection) if it is the most appropriate action. The revenue officer must ensure there will be expected net proceeds from the sale and all IRM and IRC requirements are followed. Note: Taxpayers who continue to pyramid liabilities after contact are considered “won’t pay” taxpayers as indicated in IRM
, “Will Pay”, “Can’t Pay”, and “Won’t Pay” Factors, and the revenue officer must proceed with collection. (
) If the liability is not fully paid during initial contact begin the TFRP for possible assessment (see IRM
, Determination to Pursue and Recommend Assessment of the TFRP). (
) Make a collectibility determination (See IRM

, Collectibility for those determined to be both responsible and willful for the TFRP. Note: Taxpayers who make appropriate federal tax deposits after contact and in compliance are no longer considered to be pyramiding. A TFRP nation must still be made. Follow the procedures in IRM
, Whether to Pursue the TFRP in Installment Agreement or Bankruptcy tions, and/or IRM
, BMF Installment Agreements, when considering installment agreement for these taxpayers. (
) When conducting the TFRP investigation, consider the potential for liabilities from unﬁled returns. (

) Advise the taxpayer that before an offer in compromise on employment will be investigated, one of the following must apply: • The trust fund portion of the taxes must be paid, • The TFRP must be assessed against any/all responsible/willful • The trust fund package is complete and forwarded for assessment, or • A determination made to not assert the TFRP due to criteria Note: If an offer in compromise is submitted prior to completing the required fund recovery penalty investigation actions, it will be returned without rights (See IRM
, Offer Submitted Solely to Delay Collections, IRM
, Responsibility of Offer Examiners, Offer Specialists, and Field Revenue Officers and IRM
, Trust Fund Liabilities). (

) In-business taxpayers who submit an offer in compromise on employment taxes must demonstrate compliance by making timely federal tax deposits timely ﬁling their tax returns while their offer is considered. Advise the if they fail to make timely FTDs, an offer that was previously deemed able will be returned without appeal rights (See IRM
, Return for Failure to Make Timely Federal Tax Deposit).
Repeater or Pyramiding Taxpayers 5.7.8
The repeater taxpayer’s history of non-compliance is an important factor when contemplating the seizure of an in-business taxpayer’s assets (See Policy Statement P-
and IRM
, Policy Statements for the Collecting Process ). If the taxpayer accrues additional unpaid trust fund liabilities after contact, conduct a risk analysis and a seizure should be made (see IRM

,Alternative Methods of Collection) if it is the most appropriate action. The revenue officer must ensure there will be expected net proceeds from the sale and all IRM and IRC requirements are followed.
) If the liability is not fully paid during initial contact begin the TFRP for possible assessment (see IRM
, Determination to Pursue Recommend Assessment of the TFRP). (
) Make a collectibility determination (See IRM

, Collectibility for those determined to be both responsible and willful for the TFRP. Note: Taxpayers who make appropriate federal tax deposits after contact in compliance are no longer considered to be pyramiding. A TFRP nation must still be made. Follow the procedures in IRM
, Whether to Pursue the TFRP in Installment Agreement or Bankruptcy tions, and/or IRM
, BMF Installment Agreements, when installment agreement for these taxpayers. (
) When conducting the TFRP investigation, consider the potential for liabilities from unﬁled returns. (

) Advise the taxpayer that before an offer in compromise on employment will be investigated, one of the following must apply: • The trust fund portion of the taxes must be paid, • The TFRP must be assessed against any/all responsible/willful • The trust fund package is complete and forwarded for • A determination made to not assert the TFRP due to criteria
(03-09-2017) Trust Fund Recovery Penalty Procedures
(2) Make a collectibility determination (See IRM 5.7.5, Collectibility Determination) for those determined to be both responsible and willful for the TFRP.

Taxpayers who make appropriate federal tax deposits after contact and are in compliance are no longer considered to be pyramiding. A TFRP determi- nation must still be made. Follow the procedures in IRM 5.7.4.8, Determining Whether to Pursue the TFRP in Installment Agreement or Bankruptcy Situa- tions, and/or IRM 5.14.7, BMF Installment Agreements, when considering an installment agreement for these taxpayers.

, Trust Fund Liabilities). (

) In-business taxpayers who submit an offer in compromise on employment taxes must demonstrate compliance by making timely federal tax deposits and timely ﬁling their tax returns while their offer is considered.
